div.p: 1. V:15. Sunday.

I versified one Stanza of the 53d. Psalm; but it took me all the morning to my breakfast time— I am willing to think the increase of difficulty is not entirely owing to the hebetation of my faculties; but that it is partly intrinsic— In the 53d Psalm—though consisting only of six verses, there are three transitions of persons; the congruity of thought is as often broken— The subjects are changed, and there is no apparent connection between them— It begins by declaring the Atheist a fool— It proceeds by asserting the universal depravity of mankind— It then turns to the workers of iniquity as
eating up the People of God like bread— Then apostrophises some one, as having put them to shame, because God despised them— And concludes by a prayer for the Salvation of Israel— In such diversities of thought, it is not possible to infuse a principle of unity— I followed the transitions, and shall make the Psalm a collection of Scraps— I heard Mr Crafts of East-Bridgwater—in the forenoon from Proverbs 28.14—“Happy is the man that feareth alway”—part of the verse; and in the afternoon, from John 18.36. “Jesus answered, My Kingdom is not of this World.”—also part of a verse— Mr Crafts is a young man; formed at the Theological School at Cambridge, and has the peculiarities belonging to it— Rational Theology; cool reasoning; benevolent morality, with a spice of dulness— Mr Price Greenleaf returned my Tumbler of buried Acorns; none of which have yet come up— I called at Mr John Greenleaf’s and delivered a packet from his Son, at Washington; and afterwards with Mrs Adams: at my brothers— Both his daughters are better— Mr John Angier, of Medford, the young man to whom Abigail is engaged to be married, was there— I wrote to my Son John—but my difficulty of writing increases both from the inflammation of my eyes and the infirmity of my hand.
2. V.15— Monday—

My brother called upon me this morning, and mentioned to me the state of his affairs and his prospects with regard to his children. His daughter Abigail on the point of Marriage with Mr Angier— His eldest Son the Lieutenant he expects here upon a furlough— His Son Isaac Hull has been three years in the Counting house of Dyer and Blake in Boston, but his situation there is not satisfactory; and he wishes to take him away. I told him if he did so, and Isaac wrote a good hand, he might pass the Summer with me, and I should employ him to copy Letters, and our papers for me— His board for which he now pays three dollars a week would then cost him nothing, and I would allow for such additional compensation as I could reasonably afford. His Son John Quincy is now at the Exeter Academy; chiefly at my expence— His father proposes to remove him to Mr Angier’s school at Medford, where he thinks more particular attention will be paid to his improvement in his studies by Mr Angier himself— And to this I consented: He thought some further arrangements might likewise be expedient, of his Notes and Mortgages to me— The Medford Estate having been when mortgaged to me in 1819 held in common with Mr Felt; but being now divided. Deacon Spear was here, and paid me 279 dollars, the balance of his Note given last November for the wood sold standing, near the Railway— I had some conversation with him also respecting my property here; part of which remains undisposed of— I visited my Garden. The Apple trees best up are those planted in the book boxes, and nearest the surface. There is also in the book-box N. 2. a row of 12 wild cherries up from the Stone— The Wood-house Apple, and the Penn’s Hill Redstreak come up with certainty from the seed— I am not sure of any others— Almost all the Inscriptions upon my Stakes are effaced— Those upon the Stories remain— I was occupied almost the whole day upon the arrears of this day, struggling with the suffusion of my sight, and the impotence of my hand.
3. V.15. Tuesday.

Finished the version of the 53d. Psalm, like the extracting of a tooth. It absorbed the Morning till breakfast— My brother was here, and had a Letter from his Son the Lieutenant who has received his furlough, and expects to be here about the sixteenth of this Month. I had morning visits from Mr John Marston, and the Revd. Mr Potter, officiating here as Minister of the Episcopal Church. My Son Charles and his wife came out from Boston and dined with us— They returned home in the Evening; but promised to come and spend part of the Summer with us— After dinner I visited with Charles the Garden
and Nursery; and then the Orchard and forest which I planted last November, upon Mount Wollaston— In the Nursery I found two large plants, coming out of the ground, and there were two of the same kind which had apparently been out three or four days— I took them to be Horse Chesnuts— At Mount Wollaston, we found all the trees I had set out last fall living; but the bark of a few of them eroded by field mice; from two to three feet above the surface of the ground— De Grand came out from Boston and spent the Evening with me; talking almost entirely upon politics which are nauseating— I return to my plantations with intense interest, and can take scarce any pleasure in any thing else.
4. IV:30. Wednesday.

I took up for versification the 19th. Psalm— That which Addison has beautifully paraphrased in English, and Jean Batiste Rousseau in French— They both called their Poems Odes; and Addison has referred only to the first part of the Psalm— I intend to adhere closer to the original than either of them; and as it is perhaps the most beautiful Psalm of the whole collection, I would earnestly wish to do it Justice, as far as my poor ability can extend— I spent most of the forenoon in my Garden and Nursery where I find out of the ground from my last years plantations about

most of the Pears are from seeds of the Saint Germain tree from which I planted 5. Cores and 10 seeds on theof November— Of these about 30 trees have come up and the experiment has thus far been successful— The seeds of the Saint Germain pear in the Garden are prolific. The wood-house Apple, and the Penn’s hill Redstreak are equally certain— I have as yet certainly ascertained nothing else. Dr George Parkman paid me an afternoon visit; but it was too much abridged— I called towards Evening at my brothers, and met at his door his daughter Elizabeth with his Son John Quincy, just arrived from Exeter for the Vacation. They were coming down to my house. I saw Abigail who is convalescent— On returning home, I was unable to read.
5. IV:30. Thursday.

My brother was here this Morning, and told me that he had given notice to Messrs. Dyer and Blake that his Son Isaac Hull would leave them next Saturday, and that he would then be ready to come and reside with me for the Summer— My only other visitor this day was the veteran Rufus Davis who came to speak to me, about my Cherry-tree Salt marsh lot and its want of fencing— My Morning Stanza from the Psalms is perplexing in the extreme; and I am searching in vain to discover why I find it more difficult to translate the Epistle from Briseis to Achilles, than I did those from Penelope to Ulysses and from Phyllis to Demophoon— I have more facilities for understanding the original— Having the Ovid of Heinsius from my own Library; and that of Burmann from my fathers—besides a French prose translation of the Heroïds by Martignac. Still I make no progress— By way of enquiry and consolation I thought of reading some dull Poetry with harmonious versification— I read about half the first book of Dwight’s Conquest of Canaan, which is of that description— Visited my Garden and Nursery— Found only three or four new comers; or perhaps plants which were out, but which I had not before
perceived— Towards Evening I walked to Mount Wollaston, and examined every hill where I had planted pomace last November of the hundred hills, there are fourteen only on which one or more plants from the seed have appeared— I propose to make the examination once a week until the whole Season of the appearance of plants shall have passed— I walked home by the ride, and attempted to read a Chapter of Walter Scott’s Demonology and Witchcraft, but was obliged by the dim suffusion over my eyes, to desist.
6. IV. 15. Friday. Fahrenheit 36— Frost in the Night.

Mrs Adams went to Boston this Morning, and returned in the Evening. She brought me out my ruby Pen, and a Volume from Dr. Parkman, containing Mr F. C. Gray’s Letter to Governor Lincoln, concerning the University at Cambridge— And also a set of Michaux’s North-American Sylva, which Charles had at last procured for me. Mr Bailey paid me an afternoon visit and my brother was here— Near Sunset I walked to the Cross-road near Neponset-Bridge and back— On returning stopp’d to spend an hour at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s— He and Mr Thomas Greenleaf with their Ladies were at their Square Table of Whist— I passed much of the Morning in my Garden and Nursery— Found only four new seedlings— Peach and Apple— But I laid out two beds in the garden for transplanting the Seedlings which have come up in my flower Pots and book-boxes— Took up 21 Seedling Trees from the Pots where I had planted five Cores and ten Seeds of Saint Germain 17. November last, and set them out near the Summer-house Cellar where the Vine has been extirpated, leaving still nine or ten Seedlings in the Pot— I took up four of the five Horse Chesnuts in the Summer-house Cellar, and set them out at the four corners of my new seedling-bed; and I had twenty suckers taken up from under the Mazzard Cherry tree in the lower Orchard and set out in my seedling bed— The transplantation of my Seedlings from the flower Pots and book boxes is now my most critical operation; but if one third of those that have come up will live, I shall have a large stock of young Trees of the present year— But I fear that nine tenths of my last years Plantations will fail to come up from having been planted too deep— Of my seedling Apple trees of 1829. there are ten which have survived the Winter, and I am now in hopes will live to bear engrafting in two or three years— My Elms and English Oaks are all flourishing; but the latter have grown up hideously crooked— My Poetry languishes as my Nursery thrives— Matter of fact and imagination do not well amalgamate together— I read half the first Book of Blackmore’s Creation— Commended by Addison and Johnson—ridiculed by Pope and Swift— I found in it one line worthy of remembrance“There’s no Philosophy without a God.”
7. V. Saturday.

The Morning is still absorbed in composing one Stanza of versification of a Psalm; and being now upon the 19th. I have a peculiar ambition to do it well— If in those sacred writings it may be allowable to compare one with another, I should say this is one of the most beautiful, if not the most beautiful of the whole collection of the Psalms— It contains two great associated ideas— First that the firmament of Heaven is a demonstration of an omnipotent creator— And secondly that his Laws, Statutes, and Judgments are the demonstration of his moral perfection— The illustrations of these two ideas, are very impressive— The personification of Day and Night, with the Description of the Sun and his daily course over the firmament, and the similitudes of the Bridegroom, and the strong racer form a body of oriental imagery of great power; while the conclusion of devout prayer for purification from
open and secret Sin, and for acceptance of thought and word by the creator of the universe spread over the whole Psalm an unction of tenderness and piety at once pathetic and sublime. Addison has paraphrased only the first part of the Psalm, which relates to the physical Creation only— Rousseau has taken the whole Psalm, and has made up from it the most beautiful of his Odes— The versions of Tate and Watts are failures; though Watts has tuned it to three different measures— I am not worthy to attempt a version of it, after these masters— Pope in his serious mood should have versified the Psalms— Not however as he did travesty the first Psalm— It is said in the Biographical Dictionary, that Pope’s inextinguishable hatred of Blackmore originated in a remark published by Blackmore censuring him for this scandalous and most indecent parody— I read this day the remainder of the first Book of Blackmore’s Creation— It is only a paraphrase of the 19th. Psalm; as indeed is the whole Poem. In looking into the Volumes of Additions to Pope, I found a short Poem of 21. Stanza’s in the regular, Italian Ottava Rima Stanza; which I thought had been first introduced into English by Lord Byron— This is by Gay—but has neither double rhymes—nor the tone of serio-comic drollery which belong to the Ariostan School— Visited my Nursery and Garden—only two or three new seedlings coming up—all peaches. Received this Morning a Letter from T. B Adams junr. to his father—dated the 4th. at New-York where he had arrived after a passage of six days, from Charleston S.C—and he proposes leaving New-York to come here this day or to-morrow. A. H. Everett and J. B. Davis came from Boston this afternoon, and spent it with us. I planted four Seeds of the Honey-Locust, from a pod, two or three years old—in Book-box N. 1.
8. IV:30. Sunday— South-East Rain-Storm.

Heard Mr Whitney of Hingham, in the Morning from Proverbs 3:35. “The wise shall inherit glory.” He explained the meaning of the term wise in this text as synonymous with religious; and that glory meant honour. He analysed the other sources of honour as held in the estimation of the world, and compared them with the honour derivable from religion, both in this and the future life, and shewed how far the honour resulting from religion, transcended all others. His afternoon text was from 1. Thessalonians 4.11. “And that ye study to be quiet, and to do your own business.”—first part of the verse— Mr Whitney dined with us— The day was Stormy, with copious rain, from the Southeast— My brother was here after the evening Service; and communicated to me some of his troubles, which are many and great— I advised him to apply for a Midshipman’s warrant for his Son Joseph— Isaac Hull has left his situation in Boston at Dyer and Blake’s and will come to me to-morrow. I received this Morning from the Revd. Andrew Bigelow of Medford, a Volume recently published by him of Travels in Malta and Sicily, with Sketches of Gibraltar in 1827—accompanied by a very kind and complimentary Letter. It was brought by Mr. Angier. I read a few pages in it, and was pleased with them; but was checked by the complaint of my eyes. Visited my Garden and Nursery this Morning for a few minutes only— The peaches continue to shew themselves on the Surface— Vegetation otherwise very sluggish.
9. IV.15: Monday. Sun roseFahrenheit 50.

First morning since my arrival here, that the Sun has risen clear. I believe that on the average of the year round this incident occurs twice at Washington to once that it does here. The wind came round to Northwest and grew colder as the day proceeded— My brother’s Son
Isaac Hull Adams came to reside with us during the Summer, and I advised him respecting the course of occupations and studies that he is to pursue— In the garden and Nursery I discover every day some new tree from seed or Stone, coming up; but never where I look for them; never where I had planted with the greatest care and pains— One cherry tree this day first appeared, from the rows which I planted at the lower end of my Nursery, and there is no sign of more— I had several Slips of Current bushes set out; and after dinner emptied one of my Quart Tumblers where on the 15th. of October last I buried seven white Oak Acorns— Every one of them has a tap-root extending to the bottom of the Tumbler; and two had put up a sickly shoot above the Surface— I set them all out in the Garden, and also planted a number of pignuts which had been kept over the Winter— My red Oak commencing upon its fourth year is putting out vigorous shoots; but has been much bent by the Snow— One of the two small Oaks of the second year has survived the Winter, and is putting forth shoots— The other is dead— I took a walk this afternoon, over the hills, and found that my Tenant Farrar, had cut down upon my grounds a large number of fruit trees— Particularly an old wild Cherry tree which I valued highly— I met Lewis Bass, who spoke much of Lots of Land which he has rented of me, and of fencing them— I told him I would go to the Penn’s Hill farm to-morrow— Lieutenant T. B. Adams junr. arrived at his father’s House this Evening— The condition of my eyes interdicted reading and writing after dark, and I retired by nine in the Evening, unwell to bed.
10. IV:15.— Tuesday— Sun roseFahrenheit 36.

Sharp frost last Night— Wind Northwest; and most of this day— Towards evening, moderated— Lieutenant T. B. Adams, with his Sister Elizabeth was here this morning. After dinner I walked over the hills to Deacon Adams’s to see him; but he was in Boston— I rambled over my fields, and then walked up Penn’s hill to the Bridgwater Road— Saw as I was returning Harvey Field and William Field— Harvey is building a large new house; partly over the spot where the old one was— William wishes to take my house, and the adjoining land for five or seven years— I called at Mr Marston’s, but they were just sitting down to the tea-table. I proposed to repeat my visit another day— Coming home I met Deacon Spear and Noah Curtis, who spoke of Goose-pasture; fence-mending, and House lots on Penn’s Hill. Afterwards E. Price Greenleaf, who discoursed of plantations and seeding trees—and whom I invited to come and see my Nursery— Mr George W. Beale, and his Son George spent part of the Evening with us— Nursery— In the young Elm-tree Square there are this day 17 Seedling peaches up— And only three others in all the rest of the Nursery— This afternoon, I emptied my second Quart Tumbler of the white Oak Acorns buried in it the 15th of October last I had put into it 8 acorns. I found now ten roots, all extending to the bottom of the Tumbler and all in perfect preservation— Two of the Acorns bore twin Roots, each perfect and separate from the other; and each attached to half the Acorn, which had cast off its shell and skin and appeared entirely unconsumed— I set them out in the Garden, and planted also a number of Shagbarks and Pignuts— All the Chesnuts which I attempted to keep over winter are mouldy—though they have been deep immersed in dry sand.
11. IV:15. Wednesday— Sun rose

I had intended and prepared to go to Boston this Morning, but my brothers daughter Abigail, wishing to go to-morrow, and being yet in feeble health requested the opportunity of going in our Carriage, and I postponed my business there. Finished my version of the 19th. Psalm— This day fifty years ago, I completed a Translation into French, of the Fables of Phaedrus, which I had bound in a Volume and have preserved. A blank page is left to every leaf, and taking out the book this Morning I versified in English the
Prologue— My brother was here: going to Boston— In my Nursery I discovered only one new Peach and one Cherry seedling tree— Broke up the Surface of the ground in several rows, where the seeds and Stones were planted too deep— Attended the Town meeting this afternoon— There were indeed two Town Meetings; and a Parish Meeting between them— The first was to choose a Representative in the State Legislature—Captain John Souther was re-elected—and also to take the vote of the Inhabitants upon a proposed amendment to the Constitution of the State— So that there should be only one Session of the Legislature yearly; and that to commence in January— The vote of the Town was 45. for this Amendment, and 63 against it— This town-meeting was over before I got to the house— A Parish Meeting was then held—at which various business was transacted. Noah Curtis the former Parish Treasurer has declined serving longer—and Lemuel Bracket elected in his place had also decline— There was now an election by ballot, and Lewis Bass was chosen— Upon being informed that the usual bond required was of 10.000 dollars, he also declined, and George W. Beale was chosen— The business of this Meeting done; the second Town-Meeting was held. A moderator was chosen by Nomination, and I found myself most unexpectedly called to take that place— I was so hoarse that I could scarcely speak; but I thought it would be affectation to make an excuse, and I took the place without hesitation— There were six or seven Articles in the Warrant of the Meeting, upon all which the Inhabitants acted with much harmony, and prompt despatch; and the Meeting adjourned about Sunset— I wrote a Letter this Morning to Dr Waterhouse.
12. IV. Thursday. Sun rose

I went into Boston this Morning with my brothers daughters Abigail S. Adams and Elizabeth C. Adams, and his son Isaac Hull Adams. We stopp’d at My Son Charles’s house— Abby executed a power to me, authorising me to be the Trustee of a Sum of two thousand dollars which she is about to invest in the Massachusetts Hospital Life Insurance Company— She then went with her Sister to her Aunt Foster’s where she is to spend some days— I then went to Charles’s Office; endorsed to him the order of my Son John upon Cazenove and Company, for which he received from them a Bank Check— I went to the Office of the Life Insurance Company, and there received from Mr Bowditch the Deed in Trust; the interest of which is to be received annually for the use of my niece independent of the controul of her husband; and with the deed was a power in blank, to be executed by me to any person whom she may authorise to receive the yearly interest for her— While transacting this business, Mr Bowditch introduced Mr Amos Laurence, one of the Directors of the Company, upon whom he said much of their business depended, and while our business was transacting, I had much miscellaneous Conversation with them; chiefly upon European Politics. On returning to Charles’s Office I gave him the deed and powers; to finish the business with Abigail, who is to be married next week— I dined with Charles, and after dinner visited my old friend Judge Joseph Hall, and Alexander H. Everett— The Judge is much broken down. Within the last six Months he has successively lost his wife and daughter by Consumptions— He appears to take little interest in the affairs of the world; but said he had found some relief in constant engagements of business— His Son, who is a Teller in the U.S. Branch Bank came in while I was there— Mr Everett is in the prime of Life, and has not yet suffered from the Calamities which crowd upon old Age— We had a long, animated Conversation; chiefly upon the late decision of the Supreme Court of the United States on the case of the Cherokee Indians; with which he was not satisfied— He thinks the Cherokees a foreign State— I thought the decision
right and we had some discussion upon the question of Indian Rights. Returning to Charles’s house, I went with him and his wife, and I. H. Adams to the exhibition of Statuary by H. Greenough— A group of two boy Angels reading a scroll inscribed gloria in excelsis—and with wings separable from the Statues; and two small copies of his large busts of my father and of me, were of the recent importation— The large bust of President Quincy was also there—a very fine likeness— There were two large oval Medallions, with the Sculpture in relief—Allegorical Representations of Morning and Night, by an Italian Artist, who to represent Night has a female figure, asleep; flying, with two sleeping Infants in her arms— A strange conceit, but very beautifully executed— We then left Charles and his wife, and I returned home to Quincy— Mr Thomas Greenleaf spent part of the Evening with us.
13. IV. Friday— Sun rose.

W. Field called here this Morning, upon the subject of the House and Land at the foot of Penn’s Hill which he proposes to rent of me for five years— I was not prepared for making arrangements with him, and asked him to call again to-morrow, which he promised to do— I planted this day part of the Nuts and Acorns which I had kept over winter, for Spring planting— The Chesnuts are all mouldy— The walnuts and Acorns all float— I do not expect that one of them will ever come up. Yet they were kept in a large box, deeply buried in sand. My next experiment should be to bury them deep in the ground sub Jove— The vegetation in my Nursery is sluggish— Horse chesnuts, Peaches, and here and there an Apple and more rarely a cherry tree, continue to come up— But the Sun begins already to kill them— I am not now surprised that so few persons raise fruit trees from the seed and Stone— It is an exceedingly delicate and difficult operation— Perhaps one good mode of raising Seedlings is to plant them under the old trees probandum est— After dinner I emptied the flour pot in which I had buried the nuts of the Pinus Pinea given me last Autumn by General Dearborn (16. October 1830) Almost all of them were in full vegetation; had sent roots down to the bottom of the Pot, and were putting out their shoots at the surface of the Pot— I set them out at various places of the Garden— Walk to the Mount-Wollaston Orchard with Isaac H. Adams— Found seedling Apples up in 22 of the 100 hills— The ground was not sufficiently broken up, and the seeds in many of the Hills, appear to have been choaked by the luxuriant growth of grass. Of the border plantations Isaac discovered three Chesnut seedlings just up, and I one Chesnut Oak. No Walnuts— No Buttons—but a few Self-planted Limes, under the Trees— We took up in front of Mr D. Greenleaf’s Garden, a few Seedling Limes, and Cherries, self planted, and set them out in my Garden— The Horse Chesnut and the Lilacs in my front yard, are this day opening— There is a short notice of the state of the Season, published in the Daily Advertiser, by John Lowell, signed a Roxbury farmer— He dates the first blossoming of Cherries this year 23. April— Pears opening blossoms 1. May. Apples 6. May. He says on the whole the vegetation is earlier than for 17 years before— I assume that of each tree, the fall seedling should come up just at the time when the Parent tree begins to blossom. I read a few pages this Evening, of Moore’s Life of Byron Vol. 1. Extracts from his Diary 1813. His wretchedness—his Vanity, his profligacy, his superstition, his disbelief, of a future State, and his Genius, flashing constant lightening over all this darkness, carry a blasting and pestilential interest through the whole— It was the first Evening I have been able to read, for several weeks. My tormenting demon has made a leap from my eyes to my lungs— My dear wife has written a Poem in the Octave Stanza—founded upon the Kentucky Beauchamp Story.
14. IV:45. Saturday.

Baxter, brought out from Boston the remainder of our baggage, which came from Washington in the Caroline— William Field came here this afternoon about the house and two lots of Land, at the foot of Penn’s hill which he proposed to take for five years: but we differed about the rent for which I asked 135 dollars and he offered 120. a year—we parted re infecta. John Kirk went to Boston, this Morning, and at Evening brought me a Saddle horse
from Fobes’s stable, for trial; and I immediately rode him round the Mill pond Square he is gentle; sufficiently spirited and has a pleasant and easy trot; but trips— I was however confirmed in the opinion, that this particular exercise would be more restorative to my health, than all the medecine I can take or all the interdictions of Dr Physick— Read a few pages of Bigelow’s Travels: and a few of Moore’s Life of Byron— His Journal is amusing, and as well as his Correspondence with his bookseller, Murray, characteristic— The rapidity with which he wrote his Poems, and the pertinacity with which he revised, and corrected, and added to them in the process of publication are observable— His extreme sensitiveness to the slightest misprint is ludicrous— He was a strange compound of Genius and Profligacy—despising and adoring fame—pursued forever by the Scourge of Remorse, and flying from the Torture of his own Conscience to the composition of Poetry— In moralizing upon Fame, he measures it by the Sale of his writings, and is much annoyed at the thought that Hannah Glasse’s Cookery, and Hannah Moore’s Search for Happiness, sell as briskly as Childe-Harold— His life was that of a Savage, with alternations of voracious intemperance and long inanition. Moore is a friendly biographer, and having no more moral principle, than Byron himself palliates his vices, and embroiders his good qualities till he makes him a purely great man— In my Nursery I discovered one Chesnut seedling up, and one Apple seed leaf from row of whole Wood-house Apples, planted 31. August last. After dinner I planted in the book-box fronting my chamber window, several rows of seeds which I have kept from last Summer. Whortleberry, Black berry, Thimble berry, Grape-seeds, and Apple-seeds—experiments repeated to ascertain how these plants can be raised from the seed. In throwing up the Earth from the box I destroyed several apple-seedlings which had not reached the surface. I also turned up a pignut in the drape, which had shot forth a tap-root about two inches deep. The Seedling trees we plucked up and planted last Evening are dead—but I found two seedling peach trees up on one of the stands which I spaded up last Summer, under the old Pear-trees.
15. IV:45. Sunday.

list.item: T. B. jr and Jos. H. her Sons.

div.p:
Heard Dr Thomas Gray, of Jamaica Plains, in the morning from Psalm 104.30. “Thou renewest the face of the Earth.”— A Sermon upon the Spring— Its beauties—its enjoyments, its prospects, its hopes— Its obligations, and its liabilities to disappointment. With the analogies which it supplies to the moral condition and vicissitudes of human Life— His afternoon text was from Matthew 7.14. “Because strait is the gate, and narrow is the way, which leadeth unto life; and few there be that find it.” a verse not so congenial to Unitarian Doctrines— Doctor Gray dined with us; and happening in Conversation to mention to him that having been abridged of my reading and writing by the weakness and inflammation of my eyes, I had fallen to musing in verse, and had versified with some others the Psalm from which his text was taken, he wished to see my version— I read to him that of the 19th. of which he asked my leave to take a copy— I promised to send him one, and also of the 104th. I had as yet no fair Copy of either— He promised to call upon me again— My brother’s wife was here this Evening, after tea, and her sons, T. B. Adams junr and Joseph H— Mr Edward Miller, and Mr George W. Beale were here in the Evening— Miller going to New-York, about the end of this week— I copied my version of the 104th. Psalm—and read a few pages of Moore’s Byron. My brother is quite unwell— I visited my Garden and Nursery twice this day— After breakfast alone—and towards Evening with my nephews T. B. and J. H. Adams— In the morning I first saw a second Chesnut tree; in the Evening a new Horse Chesnut— Several of the
trees had suffered a blight— Yesterday the Wind was at Southwest, with a clear sky, and Sun at Summer heat— This morning there was a dense fog— Wind North of East— No Rain, but the atmosphere so damp that on the trees it condensated into a dropping distillation which watered all the ground beneath and around them— The wind continued Easterly all day; without rain; and remaining cloudy; the fog clearing off after Sun rise— This fog comes from the Sea— It deposits a heavy dew, not amounting to mist upon all the verdure of vegetation. But the heat or the fog following so closely upon it, has parched up and crisped the delicate just expanding leaves, particularly of the growing Oaks; and of some of the young Apple-trees— Is it not such weather which rusts all the wheat sown in this part of the Country—and forms the film which I have seen arresting the growth, and cutting off the maturity of young Gooseberries?
16. IV:30. Monday.

Fog and Northeast wind, without Rain— Chilly and Raw— I rode on horseback an hour and a half before dinner, to the manifest benefit of my health— Met Lewis Bass and Peter Turner to both of whom I spoke; and on my return home, I found at my barn door; one of them from Madison in the State of New-York, who had a pair of Carriage horses of which he wished to make sale to me, but which I did not want— While we were at Dinner I received visits from a Mr Newhall who resides at Dorchester and Surgeonof the Army, whose station is at Green-Bay; but who has been absent some Months upon furlough, and is about to return— He offered to take Letters for Mrs Boyd; but I did not ascertain his name, and know not where to send them— My brother was here this Morning: rather better than last week— He had the copy of the Record of the Court in Middlesex, of the portion of the Medford farm set off to Mr and Mrs Felt, and a description in a Letter of the portion remaining to him— He committed to the Jail at Dedham a boy, whom Isaac Farrar had taken in two or three Months since in uttermost distress; and who ran away this morning, after stealing eight dollars from a workman who lives with Farrar— I was three fourths of this day, Morning and afternoon in my Garden and Nursery— Price Greenleaf and I. H. Adams, were with me after dinner— My experiments are now so multiplied, that it would be a waste of time to record them— I emptied all the Earthen Pots, and Green buckets, in which seeds and Stones had been deposited last Autumn, and set those which had come up, out at the North-west corner of the Garden, covering them almost entirely from the radiance of the Sun with Straw— Between every two of the Seedlings I planted one of the large Shellbarks, kept over Winter at Washington—though on cracking three or four of them, they appeared too much dried up, to leave a hope that they would vegetate— In the hook’d bucket, we turned out a whole Nest of Ants, in their winged state—of which there were many thousands— There were other Insects also; and an Oak, which was growing in it, apparently very flourishing, had the tap-root eaten off so close to its neck that it must undoubtedly die— Among the Transplantations was an Apricot from one of the Stones given me last Summer by Charles’s wife— Mr Greenleaf trimmed my three year Old Mazzard Cherry Tree, and my Apricots, from one of which he took out several worms— None of the rest were attacked. The new vegetation of Seedlings, is about equal to the disappearance of the Sun Struck— A third Chesnut seedling appears; and a tree with Seed leaves different from the Apple Pear or Cherry, and which I hope is the Ash— Horse Chesnuts, and Peaches come up numerously; five or six of each this day— No Appearance of Oaks; which certainly is because they were planted too deep— In the Evening I read a few pages of Moore’s Byron, but they could not keep me awake—
17. IV:30. Tuesday.

Finished the Version of the 25th. Psalm, much to my dissatisfaction. The 19th. and 104th. of which I have promised copies to Dr. Gray are the only ones in which I have approached the approbation of my own Judgment— I received a Letter from My Son John which I answered, and one from R. Rush with an Anti-masonic Letter from him published in the York Republican of the 10th. instt. which I keep over, a day or two, to answer with due deliberation— The published Letter is in answer to certain enquiries from the Anti-masonic Committee of York County— Also Letters from Dr. Reynolds, and from William Hobby— Morning Visit from Daniel Greenleaf. After dinner, I rode on horseback to my place at the foot of Penn’s Hill; and had discussions of business with Lewis Bass—Harvey Field, William Field, and Joseph Hardwick, the last of whom paid me his rent to 1. April. The morning was so cold that I was obliged to have a fire in my chamber; but when I rode on horseback after dinner the heat was so oppressive, that I was obliged to abridge my ride, and return home— My wife took tea at my brother’s, and I walked there early in the Evening: calling on my way at Mr Whitney the Minister’s house— There I learnt the destruction of the Steam-boat Washington last Saturday Night, by a shock from the Chancellor Livingston— Mr G. W. Beale was at my brothers— I passed again several hours of the Morning in my Garden and Nursery— Observed further ravages among my tender Seedling trees from the stroke of the Sun— A further sign of Vegetation at the bottom and also at the Southeast Corner of the Nursery— But never where or what I expect— My box and Pot Plantations afford some encouragement— Whole Apples and the Cores of Pears have been planted with entire success— I. H. Adams plucked up at Daniel Greenleaf’s several seedling Cherries, which we set out in the Garden; and we discovered seedling Apples, Pears and Peaches in the Garden itself— Planted Washington Shagbarks at Centre of Earthen Pots N. 1. and 3. and whole bucket in Summer house Cellar— A last year’s Pear Core in Centre of Pot N. 2. In each of the Pots and in the tub 2 Mazzard Cherries and two Stones; kept since last Summer. Measured the growth of this years shoot on my Red Oak— 13. inches since 1. May— Shoot from the broken Horse Chesnut in the Summer-house Cellar 11 Inches— Greenleaf and Downton Strawberries in full blossom— My wild Strawberries do not blossom— Headed half down the Pear-tree upon which the Bartletts are budded. I. H. Adams shewed me the Endicott Pear-tree.
18. IV. Wednesday.

Began the version of the 8th Psalm. An Alternation of Northeastern and Southwestern Winds, varied the Temperature of the day; part of which was at Summer heat; and part chilled with a fog. I kept my chamber till dinner time; which if I mean to do any thing useful I must make a constant practice— Finished the Letter to Andrew Bigelow, and wrote a short final answer to William Hobby. Charles and his wife came out from Boston to spend some weeks with us— My brother’s daughter Abigail came with them and returned home; but is yet quite unwell. My brother was here after dinner, and went to Dedham whence he returned in the Evening. Mr Edward and Mrs Cruft, with one of their young Sons were here and Mr Francis C. Gray, who was a member of the Senate of the State last year, and has not been re-elected— Visited my Garden and Nursery after dinner— The heat of the Sun is committing ravages upon my Seedlings. No new vegetation, excepting the appearance of two or three Peach tree’s— The heat of the Sun was annoying— From six to eight I rode on horseback to Milton— Called at Dr. Holbrook’s, and requested him to call to-morrow Morning at my house, to see our Grand-child Louisa, who for two or three days has been quite unwell with a severe cough, attended with feverish symptoms.
He promised to come. After an interval of 25 days, there are further accounts from England. The Packet of 8 April, arrived at New-York last Monday— A passage of 40 days— Nothing decisive, political or commercial— Nothing favourable.
19. IV. Thursday

Doctor Holbrook was here this Morning to see the child who is better. My brother went again to Dedham and returned, after instituting a new process for commitment of Farrar’s boy, on a doubt whether the previous proceeding against him had been strictly conformable to the Statute— Charles went in to Boston, and came back to dine— Isaac Hull Adams is yet occupied in copying my father’s early Journals, which it is scarcely possible to bring into Chronological Order— I was busied part of the forenoon in arranging them— A North-east Wind with copious showers of Rain the whole day— The morning much wasted— After dinner, I made a short visit to my Garden and Nursery, where the only sign of new vegetation was a second Apple seedling from the row at the lower part of the Nursery— The rain was needed for the health of the Plants, but they are drooping under it—but the weeds luxuriate— I began a Letter to Dr T. Gray, and read a few pages of Dr Waterhouse’s Junius and of Moore’s Byron—
20. IV. Friday.

Heavy Rain with Thunder and Lightening this morning, which for some time, made it doubtful whether I could go into Boston— Finished my Letter to Dr. Gray, and commenced one to Joseph Blunt, when the rain held up and we concluded to go. I had received a Letter from Mr Abner Phelps informing me that an Anti-masonic State Convention would assemble at Faneuil Hall on the 19th. and 20th. instt. and inviting my attendance at the Meeting— I saw no good reason for declining to go, and went in with Charles in his Chaise— The Convention consisted of 70 or 80 members, from all or most of the Counties of the State— Timothy Fuller of Cambridge was the President. John Bailey and Christopher Webb, the two Senators elect from the County of Norfolk were among the members, of the rest of whom I knew only two or three Persons. I found myself seated near Mr Alden Bradford— They were calling over the roll of the members when I went in; after which two or three Reports of Committees were read, and several Speeches made—one by Ebenezer Clough of Boston, and one by Mr Bailey, in defence of a Report made by him, and which another member from Norfolk partially disapproved. In the midst of the reading of a Report; just before two O’Clock, they adjourned, and I returned with Charles to Quincy to dine— Mr Capen was there—disposed to take upon Rent the Atherton Pasture upon which I promised to call and see him next Tuesday afternoon— After dinner I visited my garden and Nursery— Not a symptom of new vegetation among my plants— Numbers that we have set out broken down and destroyed by the rain— Weeds growing thick and rank— Horse Chesnuts and Lilacs in full, open blossoms— Pear and Cherry blossoms gone— Apple-blossoms going— I wrote for about an hour— Then from 6 to 1/2 past 7. Rode my horse to Braintree, round by the new Meeting house— Observed the Bank Wall of my Penn’s Hill crumbled down Orchard— Lieutt. T. B. Adams junr. spent the Evening with us— I attempted to read a few pages of Moore’s Byron but was too much fatigued and obliged to give it up—
21. IV:15. Saturday.

I date from this day the establishment of a Rule to be observed through the Summer of abstaining from the daily visit to my Garden and Nursery till after dinner, devoting the Morning, when uninterrupted to reading and writing in my chamber. Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine. I finished the version of the 8th. Psalm. Noah Curtis was here and paid me the rent of Goose Pasture for the last year to 31. March— He mentioned the desire of Charles Hubbard to purchase half an Acre of Land to build a dwelling House upon it, at the Corner of my Penn’s Hill Orchard— I asked him his opinion of its value— He said he thought it was worth 150 dollars— I promised him an answer by this day week— I made some enquiries of Mr Curtis concerning his business. He, and his two Sons Adam and Samuel are Shoemakers, and are
making large fortunes by the business— He told me that for several years they had kept upwards of thirty men constantly at work, in making boots and shoes, chiefly for exportation to Baltimore— Charleston S.C. Savannah, Augusta and most of all to New-Orleans— They ship them all in coasting vessels from Boston, and have Agents in each of those Southern Cities who make the Sales for them— They have their hides for Sole leather chiefly from Philadelphia, where they are tann’d with white Oak bark— It gives the leather a pale saffron colour. The tanning here is done with Hemlock bark and the colour is a dark deep dingy red— I asked him why there was no Tanner in this Town? He said the business required some capital, and there was considerable delay in obtaining returns— That since the failure of Deacon Webb, there had been no Tanner here, but he thought there would be within twelve Months from this time— Adam and Samuel Curtis have built each of them a handsome dwelling house at the foot of Penn’s Hill— Adam sent Eliakim Turner here last Evening and rented my Quincy Meadow for 25 dollars which Dr Phipps and Frederick Hardwick declined to give— I wrote to Joseph Blunt. John Kirk took the Poney to Boston this afternoon, and brought back another Saddle Horse for Trial— Garden and Nursery visit after dinner— One Apple one Peach, new vegetation. Red Oak shoot 15 inches— Summer-house cellar Horse Chesnut 16 inches— Weeds appalling. Walk with Charles to Mount Wollaston.— Apple-seedlings in 24 Hills—discovered, say 30 Chesnut and 20 Oak Seedlings. Alpheus and Lemuel Spear were both there— Several of the Young Apple Trees, set out last fall have been nearly girdled by some nibbling Animal— Field mice, or Rabbits— Demolished two Caterpillars Nests— The great danger to the Seedlings now is that they will be choaked with grass— Alpheus Spear asked if I had ever known a large forest tree raised from a planted nut or seed— I told him I could shew him one— He said he was told they would all come to nothing— Still I say Nil desperandum 10 [symbols] 1831.
22. IV:15. Sunday.

Heard Mr Whitney, in the morning from Luke 19.13.—“occupy till I come.” upon the Parable of the Talents and the Napkin; and in the afternoon from Romans 13.10. “Love worketh no ill to his neighbour: therefore Love is the fulfilling of the Law.” This is the fourth Sunday since my return to Quincy, and the first that Mr Whitney has preached, in his own pulpit— This has been his usual practice from his first Settlement in this Parish—nearly thirty two years— There has been great harmony among his People until lately— They are now considerably divided, and he has lost much of his popularity— He was for some years much sustained by his ardent Politics, in unison with those of a majority of his Parishioners. The episcopal church afterwards took off several of his Society, but that has fallen off since the removal of Mr Cutler— The sect of Universalists is now the most thriving— They preach not only the doctrine of universal Salvation, but that there is no future retribution—no punishment hereafter for deeds done in the body— Yet they preach the immortality of the Soul, and that the life hereafter is a state of perpetual enjoyment to the whole human race— They call, and believe themselves Christians. To reconcile the belief of a future life, with that of a total exemption from all punishment in it is within the compass of the reasoning faculties of man and is absurd enough to be embraced as a creed— Lieutenant Adams dined with us, and my brother was here this Evening. I received a visit also from Mr Asaph Churchill of Milton— I had heard him on Friday make a Speech at the Anti-Masonic Convention; last Friday, but his personal appearance is so
much altered by age, that I did not then entirely recognize him. He came now to consult me upon a project which he had formed for a universal Language— He wishes that an address should be forwarded to the President of the United States, requesting him to instruct our Ministers abroad to the Governments where they are accredited— He thinks the Italian language would be best adapted to the purpose— I expressed to him some doubts of the practicability of the project; but he said although the members of the Lyceum, near Milton Bridge were divided in opinion upon the subject a majority of them were decidedly in favour of it— I mentioned to him that a similar purpose had once been recommended by Maupertuis but that the language he preferred was the Latin. He said he had never heard of it— Churchill was two years after me at Cambridge— A Classmate of my brother Charles— His first profession was divinity: from which he changed to a Lawyer— His life has not been undisturbed, nor blameless, but he has amassed wealth and is in some consideration— He has always been a Schemer, but never passed for insane— His plans to promote his own interest have been successful— I wrote to Dr. Waterhouse. 10 [symbols] N. 3. Garden and Nursery— Horse Chesnuts and Peaches yet appearing— Apple seedling planted in Quart Tumbler on the 14th. instt. coming up— Only eight days.— Began version of 119th. Psalm.
23. IV. Monday [symbols] N. 2.

Wrote to R. Rush— Charles began to make the assortment of my fathers papers— My brother was here this Morning, with a New Mortgage of the Medford house and farm which he left with me— Afternoon visits from Judge Hall and his Son Isaac P. Davis and Mr Shepherd. There was a Mr Smith of New-Hampshire, a theological Student at Andover, who stop’d, coming from Kingston near Plymouth, and going to Boston, with a Miss Russell— A visit of mere curiosity. Alpheus Spear came and settled with me, for the rent of Mount Wollaston farm till 31. March— I am to go down and see his ditching upon the Salt Meadow— I rode the horse, which John Kirk brought out from Boston Saturday, up to Mr Capen’s, and left word, he not being at home that I could not come to-morrow as I had promised; but would come Wednesday afternoon at four O’Clock— It was dusk when I returned home, and I found the horses trot insupportably hard— Charles read a few pages of Moore’s Byron— Garden and Nursery— I believe that in Dr Gall’s Craniology there is no bump for the faculty of combination—by which I mean the faculty of observation, united with that of combining the ideas received— This is in truth the inventive faculty; a rare gift of Heaven— I perceive in my Nursery this day two new Chesnut trees up—but almost the whole of my last Summer, and Autumn’s plantations of seeds were too deep; so that nine tenths of them will never come up. Those in my book boxes have succeeded best— The Pomace seeds do not come up well. Whole Apples and the Cores of Pears should be planted; barely covered with earth— The Sun, the frost, the woods, insects, mice, rabbits and Squirrels, Rain, and how many other enemies I know not, are fatal to young Plants— It is not surprizing therefore that the common farmers think it labour lost to attempt raising them.
24. IV. Tuesday.

I went into Boston with Charles— Met Dr George Parkman in the Street, opposite Charles’s Office, and went home with him to pay him a visit— Saw Mrs Parkman— The Doctor recommended bark in powder for the cure of Erisypelas in the head; and afterwards sent me a printed paper to the same effect— I called to visit Judge Hall, and J. B. Davis, neither of whom was
at home— I then called on F. C. Gray, and at 11. went with him and attended the Meeting of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. While I was with Mr Gray he shewed me several volumes of the Transactions of the English Horticultural Society; of which there are six Quartos with Plates of the highest beauty— I found there the history of the Downton Strawberry, of which General W. H. Sumner gave me some plants last September, part of which are now growing in my garden— I had not time to examine the books, but Mr Gray promised to lend them to me— Mr Gray gave me also a copy of the third Edition of his Letter to the Governor, concerning the Administration of Harvard University and told me that he had sent me a copy of the first Edition to Washington— At the Meeting of the Academy the only business done was the annual Election of the Officers—Mr Bowditch was re-elected President—Josiah Quincy was upon a second Ballot chosen Vice-President; in the place of Professor Farrar who declined a re-election on account of bad health—Mr John Pickering was Mr Quincy’s competitor— Professor’s Anderson and Renwick of New-York were elected members of the Academy; the Revd. Alonzo Potter of Boston, and one other person. There were about twenty Members present; among whom T. L. Winthrop, Dr. Porter of Roxbury—Dr Harris of Dorchester—President Quincy—Mr Treadwell, inventor of a machine which he invited me to go and see—Edward Everett—Nathan Hale—J. Pickering—R. T. Paine, Mr Folsom, Oliver Pollock and some others— There were no Communications— I took a Copy of the Statutes of the Academy, which were revised in January 1823— This was unknown to me, although I was then, and for several years afterwards President of the Academy. It is as it always has been a very inert body: in the blame of which I have a large share. The Meeting adjourned about 1. O’Clock, and I returned with Charles to Quincy to dine— We had heavy rain all the Morning, which reduced the number of my visits— After dinner I visited my Garden and Nursery; but it rained, and I discovered no new vegetation— What I took for the second Chesnut tree up in the Nursery, (on the 18th) proves to be an Oak— Some Insect, I suppose the beetle bug is preying upon the leaves of my 3 year old Oakling. I wrote to my Son John.
25. IV. Wednesday.

This was the day of annual Election—or of the Meeting of the Legislature of the Commonwealth at their Summer Session— It has been a day of solemn festivity, from the first Settlement of the Colony, but will be so no more— By an Amendment of the Constitution upon which the vote of the People has been recently taken there is to be henceforth only one ordinary Session of the Legislature, every year, and that is to be held in January— The Northeast Wind, Rain and fog, continued nearly the whole day. Charles did not go to Boston. Mr Capen called this Morning, and told me he was obliged to go to Boston: we therefore again postponed our Meeting at his house till to-morrow— John Turner the third Son of my late Cousin was here; having applied to me for the loan of a small sum of money. He is intending to commence his business as a Tailor, in Dedham— My brother and his Son the Lieutenant were here— Persevering in my plan of reserving the whole morning till dinnertime, for the occupations of my chamber, I wrote a Letter to H. W. Kinsman, and a few lines to F. C. Gray. Took up again for perusal my fathers Old Journals, and his Manuscript account of his own life— Charles is assorting his papers— After dinner I visited my Garden and Nursery. Planted
thirty Washington Shagbarks in a line between two of the transplanted Horse Chesnuts, and one in the Centre of the whole and Hooked buckets— Found one Apple and one Pear Seedling in the range from the three book-boxes— My wild Strawberry Plants are putting forth runners, but have not blossomed. In the Nursery Chesnuts 5 and 6 are up, and one Plum—but the Peach at the bottom of the Nursery is destroyed by the Rain or by the Beetle-bug, who has also gnaw’d off and eroded many of the leaves of my Red Oakling— I rode on horseback round the Neponset Bridge and Railway Square— News from Liverpool to 20. April.
26. IV. Thursday.

Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— Brought me Loudon’s Encyclopaedia of Gardening, borrowed at the Athenaeum— A person by the name of Daniel, who said he was of New-York, but whose speech bespoke an Irishman, came as an Agent for the American Colonization Society; with a Subscription book for the African Repository— I said I believed I received it at Washington; he said he had come to seek Subscribers in this Village; and enquired for the dwelling of the Minister, to which I gave him the direction— J. Kirke took in to Boston the second horse he had brought to me, from Forbes’s upon Trial; but who does not suit me— I Received a Letter from my Son, which I immediately answered— Resumed the writing of the sketch of my father’s Life— May I no more neglect it— Read a few pages of Dr Waterhouse upon Junius— Began a Letter to A. B. Johnson and others, upon the rates of interest in this Commonwealth—but must make further enquiries to answer theirs— It was Isaac H. Adams’s birth-day and he went to dine at his father’s— In the Garden, the appearance in Book-box N. 1. of a new Apple-seedling, shewed that the vegetation of that fruit has not yet ceased— Nursery Appearance of Chesnut seedlings 7 and 8— Half of one of my 4 yearling Apricots has suddenly withered— A new incognitum seedling up. I rode up to Mr Capen’s and went with him over my Lawyer’s Common which he wishes to take upon Rent— There was a growth of standing Pine-wood upon that lot sold in November 1829. and cut down that Winter— I now saw a beautiful growth of Oak, Chiefly white Oak, but intermixed with, black, grey, and barren’s scrub Oak, on the same Spot— I had heard and read of this phenomenon, but now witnessed it with my own eyes— There is fencing wanted upon the lot, and I agreed to give Capen an old dead apple tree, to put up a patch of wall near where it stands. I made sundry observations as I went along, which I might turn to account— Plucked up one tree or shrub, which I set out in my Garden— Saw many flowers in blossom; but neither Capen nor I knew what they were— Several wild strawberries, in blossom— The low Blackberries are also in Blossom— I walk’d home by the way of Deacon Adams’s; but he was not at home.
27. IV. Friday.

Charles brought me out from Boston the first and sixth Volumes of the London Horticultural Society Transactions which I have borrowed of Mr F. C. Gray— The Society was incorporated by George the third in 1809 and have already published six Volumes of their Transactions. Their principal member and now their President is Thomas Andrew Knight, brother of Richard Payne Knight, and one of the most voluminous writers upon agricultural subjects of modern times— My present attention is confined to the papers upon the cultivation of Strawberries— I gave also this morning an hour of desultory reading to Loudon’s Encyclopaedia of gardening— Answered a Letter from Edward C. Cooper of New-York—wrote a little, and read a little of my father’s Memoirs; and a few pages of Waterhouse’s Junius— Garden and Nursery after dinner— More seedlings destroyed than new ones come up— Catalpa in the Summer House cellar, which I thought dead is alive; also the smallest of the last years oaklings— New vegetation a single peach— Two plants appearing which I know not, besides what I take to be the
Ash— S. Farrar mowed the grass in the front and East yards and in the garden: where he cut down two growing Peachlings in one of my Stands.— In the Evening I visited Mr Edward Miller—found him and his family at Tea. His Mother and the widow of W. Smith were there— Mr G. W. Beale came in— Afterwards I went to my brother’s— His wife and his Son the Lieutenant had just returned from Medford. John and Joseph Angier soon after came in Louisa C. Smith and Susan Harrod were also there— Read a paper by T. A. Knight in the Horticultural Transactions after my return—on the culture of Strawberries.
28. IV. Saturday— Sun rose 4:36.

Charles did not go in to Boston, but was occupied all the morning in assorting my father’s papers— My brother was here this forenoon, and his Son the Lieutenant towards Evening— Mr Dodge, heretofore Consul of the United States at Marseilles, with his wife, daughter of James D’Wolfe of Bristol Rhode Island, paid us a morning visit— Mr Dodge was removed from his Office shortly after the commencement of the present Administration, and another person was appointed in his place— He now entertains a hope of being restored, and asked me if I thought there would be any impropriety in his making application for it: I said none whatever; and that it would give me pleasure if he should prove successful— He told me that in 1819. when the Son of Mr Livingston, now Secretary of State was in France, he Dodge had shewn him every attention in his power, for which Mr Livingston had repeatedly expressed to him acknowledgments; and he shewed me a Letter of Introduction which Livingston afterwards in 1821. had given him to Morgan Lewis, at New-York, which spoke those Sentiments with deep sensibility— Mr Lewis was absent from New-York, when Dodge passed through there at that Time and the Letter was not delivered, but remained in his possession. He said that he had been unsuccessful in Commercial business, owing to the misconduct of his partner Oxnard; and the Consular Office was necessary to him for his comfortable subsistence— I answered a Letter from Mr Seth Sweetser of Baltimore who sent me a sample of Platina, which he found in South America between 2 and 3 degrees North of the Equator— Read a few pages of my fathers papers; and wrote very little—too little— After dinner, found nothing in the garden and nursery— Went to Mount Wollaston, with Charles and Isaac H. Adams. Found Apple-seedlings up in 26 Hills only. I must consider this experiment as having failed. In the borders we found at least 200 chestnut, 100 Oaks, and one Shagbark only up; all in fine flourishing condition, but in imminent danger of being choaked by the matted grass which grows round them— Mr Noah Curtis came for my answer to Charles Hubbard’s proposal to purchase half an Acre of Penn’s Hill Orchard, on which to build a House. I asked him 200 dollars for a Lot of 8 Rods on the Braintree Road, and ten Rods deep: to be measured by Lemuel Humphrey, and Hubbard to make and maintain all the fencing round his lot— I paid an Evening visit to G. W. Beale—
29: IV. Sunday— Fahrenheit 82.

Heard Mr Flynt of Cohasset, in the morning from John 3.19. “And this is the condemnation, that light is come into the world, and men loved darkness rather than light, because their deeds were evil.”—and in the afternoon from 1. Thessalonians 4.17. “and so shall we ever be with the Lord.” both rational, sensible discourses, and that of the afternoon manifesting deep feeling, much injured by a sluggish ungraceful delivery. Mr Flynt dined with us—and Louisa C. Smith, and my brother’s Son John Quincy— Mr.
Dodge, the late Consul at Marseilles, and Mr Degrand came out from Boston this afternoon, and took tea with us— In the dusk of Evening I visited my Nursery; and found several Beetle-bugs on the leaves of my English Oaks— All the upper leaves of my Gray Oakling have been devoured and the growth of the stem of the present year has ceased— Its length is sixteen Inches which it acquired in three weeks from the first of this Month— The Horse Chesnut in the Summer-house Cellar, broken down in the winter, by the Snow; continues to grow— The beautiful Elm shared the same fate; it has put forth several shoots but they have scarcely attained three inches of growth— The willow has grown about a foot— This was the first day of high Summer heat— I am reading papers in the first Volume of the English Horticultural Transactions— I am seeking with an anxiety rather ridiculous, for the very first elements of information respecting the germination of Plants, and find in the Horticultural Transactions several papers of much curiosity— All the papers by T. A. Knight are valuable— The second paper, by Sir Joseph Banks is an attempt to ascertain when the Potatoe was first introduced into Great Britain— He says the manuscript minutes of the Royal Society of 13. Decr. 1693. say that Sir Robert Southwell then President, told the fellows at a Meeting, that his grandfather, brought Potatoes into Ireland, and first had them from Sir Walter Raleigh—about 1586.— Paper 13. An account of the cultivation of the American Cranberry at Spring-Grove—by Sir Joseph Banks.
30. IV.15 Monday— Fahrenheit 97.

My thermometer was at 97. in the shade; but suspended in a position where it was somewhat affected by the heat of the Sun— It was a day of extreme Summer heat— Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— I finished my answer to A. B. Johnson, N. Williams and S. Beardsley of New-York upon Usury. Read a few papers of the Transactions of the London Horticultural Society— There are 17 papers out of 65 in the first Volume, by T. A. Knight; every one of which contains matter for remembrance; if my Memory were now what it once was— My object now is chiefly to collect what is to be known upon Hybrid Plants. The propagation of Apple-trees by cuttings was a novelty to me; quite incredible— The acquisition of Apples, in three years from the seed, equally marvellous— But notwithstanding the heat I visited my Garden and Nursery after dinner— Found many seedling Trees killed by the Sun— Many drooping to die—Apple, Pear, Cherry— The Peach, Horse Chesnut, Plum, and Oak yet hold out— New Vegetation, next to nothing— One ash pod, in the last Western Stony barren row. One additional puny Chesnut—one unknown tree—perhaps the spurious Juniper— One which I took for the Sweet gum; and I believe some Currants from the seed— A peach out of place in an alley; and a button wood cutting which I stuck into the ground at a corner for a stake, putting out shoots— My grey Oakling has now its this year’s upward stem gnaw’d off by the beetle bugs; and all the collateral this years shoots the same— I sympathize with the prophet Jonah upon the loss of his gourd; but yet hope the tree will not die. I fear its growth for this year is stunted— I remark the creeping runners from the Wild Strawberry; but no blossom— Knight sets out his Strawberry beds every year anew— Sir Joseph Banks recommends the old practice of supporting them with Straw, and says they had their name thence— I was called for the garden to Zenas Humphrey and Richard Faxon— Tax collectors of Braintree, with a charge of highway tax for this, and the two preceding years— Tis for Goose Pasture— There were charges against the heirs of Norton Quincy which I declined to pay— At half past six in the Evening I went with my wife, Charles and his wife to my brother’s where John Angier of Medford was married by Mr Whitney to Abigail Smith Adams, my brothers eldest daughter— Mr Stetson the Minister of Medford
made a concluding Prayer— There were about 30 persons present— Family Connections, and immediate neighbours— None of Thomas or Daniel Greenleaf’s families. We came home about ten O’Clock.
31. IV:15. Tuesday. Fahrenheit 92.

Mr and Mrs Angier went this Morning, to spend two days at Haverhill, after which they are to go to their Residence at Medford— I received a Letter from George Clark, Postmaster at Northwest Bridgwater; about Anti-Masonry, which I answered— Also a Notice, from Abner Willett, Secretary of a Meeting of the Inhabitants of the Town, held last Evening, who appointed me with four others a Committee to procure an Orator, for an Oration in the Stone Temple on the next fourth of July— Charles brought out from Boston two pots of Keen Seedling Strawberry Vines, in bearing which we set out this Evening in the Garden— Price Greenleaf was returning from the Creek Bath, when I invited him in and he visited my garden and nursery. The Sun is killing my fresh seedling trees with fearful fatality— Scarcely one appearance of a new plant— It is the Pestilence that walketh at Noonday: as the beetle bug is the desolator of the Night— The Seedlings in the Book-boxes have hitherto escaped and are very flourishing— I found this day one Walnut which came up the 25th. of May; but which I then took for a Chesnut. What I took for Currants are probably wild blackberries. The first Lesson for an experimenter in Plantations, must be to bear disappointments with equanimity; and to expect them in the proportion of a hundred failures to one successful operation— In the Evening I called upon Mr G. W. Beale, and not finding him at home upon Mr Thomas Greenleaf; both of whom one of the Committee for the fourth of July Oration— We agreed for a Meeting of the Committee, at seven O’Clock to morrow Evening at my house— Charles told me that a man had called upon him and wished to have a Conversation with him on the Subject of my Correspondence with R. Rush upon Anti-masonry— Charles is afraid of the consequences of my expressing any opinion upon the Masonic contrary; supposing it will be imputed to selfish motives— But this is the vital essence of all political collisions— No man can escape them— And a man susceptible of being intimidated by them, is not fit for any useful agency in public affairs. I have for nearly five years abstained from taking part in the Masonic Controversy, as much as possible; but upon such questions there is a time when it becomes the duty of a good Citizen to take his side. In the conflict between Free-Masonry and its adversaries, I apprehend the Time is approaching when my duty to my Country, will require a free and open avowal of my opinions, and whatever may be the consequences I shall not flinch from it— The danger is not imaginary—nor I hope underrated by me— Consideration is a Guardian Angel—

Day— I rise between four and five O’Clock—read three Chapters in the Bible—and compose one Stanza of version of the Psalms— We breakfast between seven and eight—immediately after which Charles usually goes in to Boston; and returns between two and three to dine— About the middle of the Month I adopted the rule of reading and writing in my chamber till dinner, in which my only purpose now is to persevere— After dinner I visit my garden and nursery, and once weekly Mount Wollaston— Walk over the hill, ride, and visit my brother or my neighbours— Read or write, occasionally— There is very little evening darkness— Bed between nine and ten—
